instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00164: What is 820-00164? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.U7090: What is U7090? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V42_G3H.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.C7125: What is C7125? Capacitor between CHGR_BOOT and CHGR_PHASE important for bootstrapping creation of PPBUS_G3H on 2013-2015 macbook pros.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead no green light
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 1v 
Pp3v42 is 2.6v 
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>=0v 
I have removed <CHIP>U8150</CHIP> no changes...
No corrosion on the motherboard 
<RESISTOR>R7012</RESISTOR> is fine and f7000 is okay...
What to do?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead no green light
threads.message:
Remove F7140 and check <CAPACITOR>C7140</CAPACITOR> voltage.
Also check diode mode to ground on both sides of the fuse.

Post <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> basic voltages; pins 1, 2, 3, 9, 12, 13, 14, 15, 17, 19, 20, 27.

Did you try fake charger, or lab PSU?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead no green light
threads.message:
After removing F7140 pin1 is =0.435 pin 2 is 0.175
0V at <CAPACITOR>C7140</CAPACITOR>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead no green light
threads.message: Should i post <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> voltages without F7140

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead no green light
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead no green light
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead no green light
threads.message:
"3=0v"
Check diode mode to ground.
<CAPACITOR>C7111</CAPACITOR> and <RESISTOR>R7110</RESISTOR> are the suspects there.

Post now <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> voltages.
Check diode mode to ground at L7095.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead no green light
threads.message:
<CAPACITOR>C7111</CAPACITOR>=0.003
<RESISTOR>R7110</RESISTOR>=0.003

diode mode to ground at L7095=2.005
<CHIP>U7090</CHIP> voltages 
Pin1=1.3v
Pin2=1.942v
Pin3=4.3v
Pin4=1.9v
Pin5=gnd
Pin6=16v
Pin7=unconnected
Pin8=16v
Pin9=gnd

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead no green light
threads.message:
Remove <CAPACITOR>C7111</CAPACITOR> and check diode mode again.
If still short, replace <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.

"diode mode to ground at L7095=2.005"
Please check correctly...

Check <RESISTOR>R7095</RESISTOR>/96 values and traces.
If good, replace <CHIP>U7090</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead no green light
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7095</RESISTOR> is broken can i replace with a 200kohm resistor? 
have replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> short gone

threads.message:
Maybe bad solders.
Be sure <CAPACITOR>C7125</CAPACITOR> is good.

Post again <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> voltages.
